						               													<description>Twilight Imperium (Fourth Edition) is a game of galactic conquest in which three to six players take on the role of one of seventeen factions vying for galactic domination through military might, political maneuvering, and economic bargaining. Every faction offers a completely different play experience, from the wormhole-hopping Ghosts of Creuss to the Emirates of Hacan, masters of trade and economics. These seventeen races are offered many paths to victory, but only one may sit upon the throne of Mecatol Rex as the new masters of the galaxy.&#10;&#10;No two games of Twilight Imperium are ever identical. At the start of each galactic age, the game board is uniquely and strategically constructed using 51 galaxy tiles that feature everything from lush new planets and supernovas to asteroid fields and gravity rifts. Players are dealt a hand of these tiles and take turns creating the galaxy around Mecatol Rex, the capital planet seated in the center of the board. An ion storm may block your race from progressing through the galaxy while a fortuitously placed gravity rift may protect you from your closest foes. The galaxy is yours to both craft and dominate.&#10;&#10;A round of Twilight Imperium begins with players selecting one of eight strategy cards that both determine player order and give their owner a unique strategic action for that round. These may do anything from providing additional command tokens to allowing a player to control trade throughout the galaxy. After these roles are selected, players take turns moving their fleets from system to system, claiming new planets for their empire, and engaging in warfare and trade with other factions. At the end of a turn, players gather in a grand council to pass new laws and agendas, shaking up the game in unpredictable ways.&#10;&#10;After every player has passed their turn, players move up the victory track by checking to see whether they have completed any objectives throughout the turn and scoring them. Objectives are determined by setting up ten public objective cards at the start of each game, then gradually revealing them with every round. Every player also chooses between two random secret objectives at the start of the game, providing victory points achievable only by the holder of that objective. These objectives can be anything from researching new technologies to taking your neighbor's home system. At the end of every turn, a player can claim one public objective and one secret objective. As play continues, more of these objectives are revealed and more secret objectives are dealt out, giving players dynamically changing goals throughout the game. Play continues until a player reaches ten victory points.&#10;&#10;&mdash;description from the publisher&#10;&#10;</description>

      <image>https://cf.geekdo-images.com/d_ot5Xn40OoeCLIOHlL9jQ__original/img/9evrXL5YOB3GLaAG_psyKWGd27k=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic455213.jpg</image>
                                     				
				<name type="primary" sortindex="1" value="Cosmic Encounter" />
			
						                           
						               													<description>In Cosmic Encounter, you play the leader of a colonization effort whose ships are traveling throughout the Cosmos to prove their worthiness for Cosmic leadership.  Each player is a race that has the ability to bend or break certain rules in the game.  You will use force, cunning, and diplomacy to win success for your unique form of alien intelligence.  Battles are determined through the use of cards in addition to assistance from other players around the table.  The winner(s) will be the first player(s) to have FIVE COLONIES on any planets outside his or her home system.&#10;&#10;This is an updated version of the original Cosmic Encounter (1977).&#10;&#10;Major differences between this version and the Eon version:&#10;&#10;&#10;     Terminology was changed for many components and rules: Compromise to Negotiate; Consolation to Compensation; Edicts to Artifacts, etc.&#10;     Both the Eon version and Mayfair Games' version used tokens to represent players' forces.  Avalon Hill changed them to plastic ships, and changed the system pieces as well, and the Hyperspace Cone became a Ship carrier.&#10;     Mayfair's version used cardback art similar to Eon's, so the two could theoretically be combined.  Avalon Hill used all new art on the cards, and the stock is much thinner.&#10;&#10;&#10;</description>

						               													<description>BILLOWING SMOKE FROM THE NORTH - As battles wage through Skulk Hollow, a thick, dark, haze appears around Maul Peak. The smell of war wafts down through the valley as clouds of wrath engulf towns and villages. As fate spreads the smoke far and wide, destruction follows. A foxen scout, their fastest, is hastily&nbsp;dispatched to learn more...&#10;&#10;Maul Peak is a two-player, asymmetric, tactical combat game in which players take the roles of either a tribe of bears or a towering behemoth of a Guardian.&#10;&#10;Maul Peak is a standalone sequel to the original game Skulk Hollow, and all Guardians / Heroes can be pitted against each other. All new guardians work with the original Foxen Heroes &amp; Map, Bears vs old Guardians, Bears vs new Guardians &mdash; you name it!&#10;&#10;Combining the two games also allows up to 4 players to pit 2 guardians vs both bear and foxen heroes for Epic Battles.&#10;&#10;     One vs Many Asymmetric Combat creates a fresh, fun, 2-player experience.&#10;     Action takes place on the Board AND the Guardian. Not only does the battle occur on the Kingdom board, but the bear must traverse full size, Guardian gameboards. Each guardian has unique routes and abilities to stop the bears. &#10;     Dual Purpose Cards give players a wide range of movement and ability powers while keeping them quick to pick and easy to play.&#10;     Unique Bear Leaders and Guardians creates a range of tactics and dynamics, adding depth and strategy that makes each game a new challenge.&#10;&#10;&#10;&mdash;description from the publisher&#10;&#10;</description>

         <thumbnail>https://cf.geekdo-images.com/wycq-tJqtKsUkYADq8Z3BQ__thumb/img/UFcTi7i4rbCy1a05mztemxSDL5I=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic7083310.jpg</thumbnail>
      <image>https://cf.geekdo-images.com/wycq-tJqtKsUkYADq8Z3BQ__original/img/6K49PugCJeHYWOuapYfKBN92e5w=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic7083310.jpg</image>
                                     				
				<name type="primary" sortindex="1" value="Skulk Hollow" />
			
						                           
						               													<description>THE GREAT RETURN&#10;&#226;&#128;&#139;Over generations and generations the ancient woodland of B&oslash;re prospered and grew. The world was bestowed with great spirit, which lifted the animals of the land to new heights. Unfortunately, over the years these clans lost touch with the spirit of the land and faction warring developed. The Foxen Kingdom of Skulk Hollow in the South, The spiritual Red Pandas of Cupboard in the North, the Mischievous Mice of Multon in the West, and the colony of Blackheart Bunnies in the East. As skirmishes started breaking out across the continent, lives lost, there was a monstrous shake and then The Great Return. No one quite knows why, but the Guardians have risen - but not the kind, life-giving Guardians of spiritual legend. Dark, ferocious, versions that are now attacking all the kingdoms of the land.&#10;&#10;OBJECTIVE&#10;In Skulk Hollow, two players take the roles of either a towering behemoth of a Guardian trying to eliminate the clans of foxes who have been causing havoc on the countryside, or a band of foxen heroes out to vanquish the evil beast that has been terrorizing the land and reunite the four kingdoms of B&oslash;re.&#10;&#10;The Guardian wins the game by either eliminating the Foxen King, or by gaining enough Tribute.&#10;&#10;The Foxen Heroes wins the game by eliminating the Guardian.&#10;&#10;GAMEPLAY&#10;Skulk Hollow is a 2-player, asymmetric, tactical combat game. Player use action cards to move their units, summon, and use special abilities. Taking down a guardian requires the Foxen player to leap onto the Guardian player board and take out different parts of the character.&#10;&#10;</description>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?><items termsofuse="https://boardgamegeek.com/xmlapi/termsofuse"><item type="boardgame" id="159911">
         <thumbnail>https://cf.geekdo-images.com/vbSz3s6Ddi1jolqPLA0Mpg__thumb/img/gqxwG_iE3Qz49AM2QeI-itBhRoQ=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic2037476.jpg</thumbnail>
      <image>https://cf.geekdo-images.com/vbSz3s6Ddi1jolqPLA0Mpg__original/img/uzNOcMvKJivKbf6wbTEZIDxs8GM=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic2037476.jpg</image>
                                     				
				<name type="primary" sortindex="1" value="Euphoria" />
			
						                           
						               													<description>From the back of the box (translation from spanish):&#10;&#10;&quot;Each night two teams will fight to be a step closer from the goal, that big target, the dream of everyone of them, the great $300.000 reward to make their dreams come true. There is no rules, all is allowed, and for once It is the end that justifies the means.&#10;&#10;Take your seats, get ready to watch something will leave no one indifferent, the newspapers will write about it for days, at your home, at your work, everytime, something never seen before on TV.&#10;&#10;EUPHORIA, THE ULTIMATE REALITY SHOW IS ABOUT TO BEGIN-&quot;&#10;&#10;Euphoria is an estrategy game for two players with 2 teams of 4-6 miniatures (clones for the &quot;show&quot;) each. There is no, factions, armies, countries, or whatever, each team is a band freely arranged by the player up to a maximun cost of points called &quot;audience&quot; here.&#10;&#10;Each character has different attributes, skills and special rules and habilities/powers (once per &quot;show&quot;).&#10;&#10;You either can play a mission scenario with an objective (i.e. Rescue a character) or massacre game trying to defeat your opponent's team. The match is limited to 10 rounds (Typical game: 1 hour long with Audience 800 and 4-6 minis per team in a 120x90cm table).&#10;&#10;Starter pack (&quot;VHS box&quot; package) content:&#10;&#10;- 4 Metal miniatures (Nikolai, Madeleine, Kabuki, Sooyoung) and 2+2 round bases (30mm and 40mm)&#10;- 3 Resin barrels&#10;- 5 10sided dices (2 white 0-9, 2 blue 0-9, 1 blue 00-90)&#10;- 4 Dials (0-15, required assembly)&#10;- 20 &quot;drop&quot; counters (adrenalin, healt, grenades, etc).&#10;- 65 Pags. color printed rulebook&#10;- ID Player Card&#10;&#10;</description>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?><items termsofuse="https://boardgamegeek.com/xmlapi/termsofuse"><item type="boardgame" id="382843">
         <thumbnail>https://cf.geekdo-images.com/tNO7HW6Hn_O3xY11R80pFA__thumb/img/XAQYaQnO9WiZ-dVy4QV2jN8IjYI=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic7672387.jpg</thumbnail>
      <image>https://cf.geekdo-images.com/tNO7HW6Hn_O3xY11R80pFA__original/img/9wrRs7GtVVRuNblz64QXvNJMb-4=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic7672387.jpg</image>
                                     				
				<name type="primary" sortindex="1" value="Evacuation" />
			
						                               				
				<name type="alternate" sortindex="1" value="Hexodus" />
			
						               													<description>&quot;Hurry to the ship! Twelve houses from our town have already burned down!&quot;&#10;&#10;In Evacuation, life on our planet is being burned away thanks to increasingly intense sunlight, so everyone is trying to move all the people and factories in their territories from the &quot;old&quot; planet to a new one &mdash; and they have only four rounds in which to do so.&#10;&#10;You start the game with a full functioning economy, and over the course of play, you must dismantle that economy and move it. Income on the old planet shrinks over time, and production probably won't be much better until you establish yourself on the new planet and kick things into action. Resources can't be mixed across the planets, so you need to take special care with your planning.&#10;&#10;To do this, you choose actions from the player board, with the expert variant adding cards to your hand that allow you to choose additional actions and combine them. Each action has its own value, and the sum of these actions is important for an &quot;end of the round&quot; bonus. Additionally, players move their markers along the orbital track based on the value of their actions.&#10;&#10;If you can raise production of three resources to level 8 and have three virtual reality machines on the new planet, you win. Otherwise, players compare scores after four rounds. Evacuation includes modules to add new play options.&#10;&#10;NOTE: A community FAQ is available here to provide some clarity on Frequently Misplayed Rules.&#10;&#10;</description>

						               				<minplayers value="1" />

					<link type="rpg" id="24883" value="Saga: A Rules-light Universal Roleplaying System" />
		
									
			

			               													<description>from the Introduction:&#10;To most seasoned roleplayers, Magic: the Gathering is a game that needs no introducing. It is a legend in its own right, beloved of nerds, cherished by dorks. Even those who have never played Magic: the Gathering are most likely familiar with it to some extent due to its popularity as a cultural meme. Honestly, it's pretty unlikely that you're reading this if you're not into the game or the mythos of M:tG.&#10;&#10;However, despite the tremendous popularity and near-universal presence of Magic the world over, for some reason, the game has never been adapted into a Roleplaying Game or World Setting. The campaign setting supplement you're now reading is proof that I find this fact shocking, ridiculous, and in need of fixing.&#10;&#10;from A Little About This Campaign Setting:&#10;In the rare event that you're unfamiliar with Magic: the Gathering, this campaign setting needs some explaining. The worlds (yes, plural) of the Magic: the Gathering multiverse are notably and primarily High Fantasy in flavor, with sprinklings of Steampunk gadgetry, Gothic Horror beasties, and Samurai and Ninja jidaigeki. Classical Chinese Elementalism governs everything in the Magic multiverse in the form of five symbols (fire, water, etc.). Each symbol governs and influences multiple spheres of life, the universe, and everything, and are crucial to the atmosphere of Magic: the Gathering.&#10;&#10;</description>

						               													<description>In 1271, 17-year-old Marco Polo started on a journey to China with his father and older brother. After a long and grueling journey that led through Jerusalem and Mesopotamia and over the &quot;Silk Road&quot;, they reached the court of Kublai Khan in 1275.&#10;&#10;In The Voyages of Marco Polo, players recreate this journey, with each player having a different character from history with a special power in the game. The game is played over five rounds. Each round, the players roll their five personal dice and can perform one action each turn with them. Each action requires the use of one or more dice, and can be collecting resources or money, acquiring contracts or traveling on the board. When traveling, each player begins at Venice and can decide between several routes eastward, all the way to Beijing. When a player stops at a city, they place a trading post there, giving them access to extra actions or resources for the rest of the game. The higher the value of the dice used for an action, the better the options that may be chosen, but also the more money the player must pay if an opponent has already chosen the same action.&#10;&#10;After five rounds, the game ends with players receiving extra victory points for having trading posts in Beijing, fulfilling the most orders, and having trading posts in the cities on secret city cards that each player gets at the start of the game.&#10;&#10;This game should not be confused with Marco Polo Expedition, which has the same German title.&#10;&#10;</description>

		<item objecttype="thing" objectid="175621" subtype="boardgame" collid="28736037">
	<name sortindex="1">Epic Card Game</name>
		<yearpublished>2015</yearpublished>			<image>https://cf.geekdo-images.com/DfhQjeh-IzvUMFH__QUDXA__original/img/o7b9oFEfBQ4BOtY_bOhDQ6C4Jlw=/0x0/filters:format(jpeg)/pic2691347.jpg</image>
		<thumbnail>https://cf.geekdo-images.com/DfhQjeh-IzvUMFH__QUDXA__thumb/img/TrfK1csWE7BMdCMmG8TQWLb5fAE=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic2691347.jpg</thumbnail>
			<status own="1" prevowned="0" fortrade="0" want="0" wanttoplay="0" wanttobuy="0" wishlist="0"  preordered="0" lastmodified="2021-10-11 23:50:49" />
	<numplays>5</numplays>			<comment>I resent a lot of the people who claim this "fixes" magic. It essentially removes mana and mana cards do make some games of magic devolve if you don't draw any but mana is also the engaging economy and one of the strategic puzzles in magic. It also removes a lot of the strategy, tactics, and choice that exist in magic. There's a reason that they've never printed a viable card that single-handedly destroys all creatures during your opponents turn in magic. There's a reason magic has never printed a 7-power creature which can attack, unopposed, on the first turn in magic (cheesy combos not withstanding)...

Epic isn't a bad game (though I didn't like it) but a lot of the timing and choices and restriction that make magic a compelling game for millions of players are stripped from Epic so just be aware of who you're recommending it to.</comment>	<conditiontext>Very Good - KS Promos Included</conditiontext>			</item>

	<numplays>2</numplays>			<comment>Super swingy and unbalanced gameplay. You can rush the end game by just buying level I cards and still have a good shot at winning because no one's had a chance to build up an engine yet. The game has good ideas but doesn't incentivize you to utilize them enough allowing for too many degenerate games where nothing interesting happens. After half a dozen plays, I think I'll actively avoid playing this one again.</comment>				</item>

		<item objecttype="thing" objectid="231450" subtype="boardgame" collid="53601271">
	<name sortindex="1">Lucky's Misadventures: Episode 42 – Lost in Oddtopia</name>
		<yearpublished>2018</yearpublished>			<image>https://cf.geekdo-images.com/XYg-jpqhYBjzaONhYlo-EA__original/img/fyDTRAaY4GnJ07dqeYeg4zZurWA=/0x0/filters:format(png)/pic3904850.png</image>
		<thumbnail>https://cf.geekdo-images.com/XYg-jpqhYBjzaONhYlo-EA__thumb/img/424iP-m21egddvv5tvj9K_Vltik=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic3904850.png</thumbnail>
			<status own="0" prevowned="1" fortrade="0" want="0" wanttoplay="0" wanttobuy="0" wishlist="0"  preordered="0" lastmodified="2023-10-19 11:52:51" />
	<numplays>2</numplays>			<comment>Maybe this game doesn't work well with 2 players but the general issues I had with this game seem so glaring that I cant believe how generally positive people are on this game. The only explanation is that these are all kickstarter backers and I'm the only person who bought this elsewhere and whose opinion isn't colored by the kickstarter process of hype and anticipation.

First off, setup for the game is on page 12 of the rulebook. There are pages and pages before that of card explanations which, without having gotten to any rules yet, completely out of context. And then the game rules themselves are written in an often over-complicated way and interspersed with asides from the designer about how hilarious his playgroup is (e.g. it says just for fun that you can stop a person's turn and force everyone to simultaneously point at who they each think is winning... yeehaw.) By the end of the game we were unable to figure out when some phases occur, what some cards do, and on top of all that we kept cringing at the publishing choices like instead of revealing 3 cards from a deck each round (which is the actual gameplay rule) you're supposed to pound the table and scream, "eat a toad !," three times or something like that while you reveal the 3 cards from a deck. The "toad" here has no relevance to anything else and appears to only exist as an opportunity for more cringing.

Then there's these cards that dictate which abilities in your hand will trigger each round which felt like such an arbitrary mechanism. I know you can hold cards in your hand from round to round to wait until they will trigger but why make timing your cards such an unpleasant, random experience when one - timing in this game can be critical and two - the abilities generally are reeeally boring anyway so there's no sense of payoff when you do wait. Examples include: "play 1 more card this turn" or "your opponent plays 1 less card this turn" or "your opponent can't make you discard cards this turn". Those abilities wouldn't be so bad if they weren't ~90% of all the card abilities. I've never seen such milk-toast, boring abilities in a deck building game. Having played many deckbuilders, my opponent and I spent the second half of the game consistently looking at the buy row with plenty of money and opting to buy nothing. And not because the cards were bad compared to wait we'd already bought before, but they were just more of the same boring cards which were already clogging our decks. By the end of the game my whole deck felt like a giant clog.

Finally there's the tinker and wicked business. You only get to play 3 cards per turn which, best case scenario, grant 2 money each, so getting enough money to buy a card that costs 9 is ridiculous (why even have cards that expensive??? even 6 money would have been an incredible feat to obtain and never happened once during our game). So there are 2 other kinds of cards which give no money but rather an opportunity to get those uber-expensive cards for free. You might think you should focus on getting lots of tinker or wicked but you need both because if you ignore either, your opponent will consistently get those incredibly expensive cards for free. And even if you do focus on getting tinker and wicked power, if you don't have the right one when the cards that cost 7+ are randomly drawn from the deck, you're out of luck. There's likely 0 chance you can buy them with money and a great chance your opponent will have a couple tinker and can snatch game winning cards for a pittance.

In fairness to the game, the rulebook does say, "don't take the game too seriously" but I wish the publisher and/or designer would have taken their design and development a little more seriously. In my many years gaming I've played several games that are worse than Lucky's Misadventures but at least my group had fun laughing at how random or ridiculous they were; this one, however, was an absolute pile.

All that said, the art is OK.</comment>				</item>

		<item objecttype="thing" objectid="361545" subtype="boardgame" collid="96543977">
	<name sortindex="1">Twilight Inscription</name>
		<yearpublished>2022</yearpublished>			<image>https://cf.geekdo-images.com/g36va6ofPCzNZXF-9GEpCg__original/img/W-Goi5-dQP19Nj-MXa8xdEtpnVs=/0x0/filters:format(png)/pic7132023.png</image>
		<thumbnail>https://cf.geekdo-images.com/g36va6ofPCzNZXF-9GEpCg__thumb/img/F8SHn9giBPmooUkmJDz9kXAamS0=/fit-in/200x150/filters:strip_icc()/pic7132023.png</thumbnail>
			<status own="1" prevowned="0" fortrade="0" want="0" wanttoplay="0" wanttobuy="0" wishlist="0"  preordered="0" lastmodified="2022-08-11 12:16:32" />
	<numplays>4</numplays>			<comment>I don't think should really be compared to twilight imperium and it really shouldn't be compared to most roll and writes.

This is a strategy game on the longer side (2 hours or so) for people who enjoy working towards combos and lots of moving parts and want a little player interaction but largely enjoy working on their own engines. The twilight imperium theme is great for me but that's the icing on the cake; this game has been a hit in its own right with everyone I've shown it to so far.</comment>				</item>

				<name type="primary" sortindex="1" value="Aladdin's Dragons" />
			
						                               				
				<name type="alternate" sortindex="1" value="Morgenland" />
			
						               													<description>This is the card game version of Aladdin's Dragons, but carries the same title as that game.&#10;&#10;In ancient and long forgotten times heroes were lured to Eastern lands by tales of bountiful treasure and powerful magic.  The treasure was found, not lying about, but in dangerous caves guarded by fierce dragons.  Those strong enough to gather the dragon&rsquo;s treasures had to compete among themselves for privileges that would smooth the way to the Caliph&rsquo;s palace.  On reaching the palace, the heroes found their way blocked by powerful guards.  Here they could pass the guards only with the right influence or, failing that, generous bribes.  Within the palace walls, the heroes bartered their hard won treasures for magical artifacts in a contest to see who could acquire the most artifacts and gain the praise of the Caliph.&#10;&#10;The Aladdin&rsquo;s Dragons Card Game (Morgenland Kartenspiel) is based on the award winning board game of the same name published by Rio Grande and Hans im Gl&uuml;ck.  The game consists of a double pack of cards and is played over a number of rounds, usually four or five in total.  Each round has three phases.  In phase one, new artifact and treasure cards are laid out.  In phase two, players play their hero cards into the various locations.  In phase three, the locations are resolved.&#10;&#10;</description>
